doc.field:
Face of Brooklyn consists of 281 digital photographic images, stored on 3 DVDs. The images are all portraits of Brooklyn residents and visitors, taken by Nora Herting at open portrait studios in neighborhoods throughout Brooklyn in 2008. Subjects volunteered to be photographed on the spot; most, photographed either alone or with friends or family, appear in front of a white background.
The artist views the collection as a response to the portraits already featured in the Brooklyn Historical Society's collection, which do not represent the diversity of Brooklyn's residents.

Face of Brooklyn consists of 281 digital photographic images, stored on 3 DVDs. The images are all portraits of Brooklyn residents and visitors, taken by Nora Herting at open portrait studios in neighborhoods throughout Brooklyn in 2008. Subjects volunteered to be photographed on the spot; most, photographed either alone or with friends or family, appear in front of a white background.
The artist views the collection as a response to the portraits already featured in the Brooklyn Historical Society's collection, which do not represent the diversity of Brooklyn's residents.

Nora Herting's born-digital collection, Face of Brooklyn, consists of 281 photographic images on 3 (4? - awaiting Red Hook) DVDs. Photographs were taken at open portrait studios in neighborhoods throughout Brooklyn in 2008. Forms with brief biographical information, signed by subjects or guardians, support the images. An Excel spreadsheet of the form information was also included on one of the DVDs.

The open air portrait studios were set up by the artist, with assistance from volunteers, in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Coney Island, Crown Heights, Fort Greene, Midwood, Prospect Heights, and Red Hook, as well as in Prospect Park and McCarren Park in Brooklyn. Subjects volunteered on the spot; most, photographed either alone or with friends or family, appear in front of a white background. The images contrast the formality of portraiture with everyday life in progress. The portraits reflect the diversity and individuality of Brooklyn's residents.

Nora Herting, b. 1979 (?), graduated Summa Cum Laude with a Bachelor of Fine Arts, Photography, from University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico, in 1999. In 2005, she received a Masters in Fine Arts from The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH. Her work has been featured in solo exhibitions, as well as in juried and group exhibitions.

Nora Herting received a grant from the Brooklyn Historical Society to make original artwork inspired by the society's collection. The collection was gifted to the residents of Brooklyn who participated as subjects, and, in October 2009, to the Brooklyn Historical Society.
The collection was donated by Nora Herting in October 2009.
Digital images are in tiff format.
